sentence: Dun & Bradstreet Corp.DNB reported fourth-quarter 2015 adjusted earnings of $2.87 per share that easily beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $2.85.
However, quarterly revenues of $499.3 million fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $505.2 million.
On an adjusted basis, total revenue came in at $504.4 million, up 8.4% year over year.
Revenues from the company's Americas segment grew 10% year over year to $422 million while that from Non-Americas declined 1% to $82.4 million owing to adverse currency translations.
On an adjusted basis, Risk Management Solutions revenues from Americas increased 10% year over year to $208.3 million.
Sales & Marketing Solutions revenues from the region also grew 10% from the year-ago quarter to $213.7 million.
In Non-Americas, adjusted Risk Management Solutions revenues declined 3% year over year to $64.1 million.
Sales & Marketing Solutions Non-Americas increased 10% from the year-ago quarter to $18.3 million.
For 2015, adjusted earnings came in at $7.25 as against $7.18 reported in 2014.
Adjusted revenues grew 5% to $1.66 billion.
On an adjusted basis, total operating costs were down 7% to $330 million.
Total operating income was $174.4 million, up 10.2% year over year.
Dun & Bradstreet ended the quarter with $365.7 million in cash and cash equivalents, as against $319.4 as of Dec 31, 2014.
Long-term debt was $1.8 billion compared with $1.4 billion as of Dec 31, 2014.
The company's net debt position as of Dec 31, 2015 was $1.5 billion.
For 2015, cash flow from operating activities was $336.8 million while free cash flow stood at $272 million compared with $297.4 million and $250.2 million, respectively in 2014.
The company raised its quarterly dividend 4% to 48.25 cents, payable on Mar 11 to shareholders as of record Feb 25.

We believe that DNB's high-margin business model, strong international growth potential, strategic investments, partnerships, accretive cloud-based acquisitions and aggressive share buyback will drive growth.

Also, the company will be able to provide a wide range of products given its partnerships with the likes of Salesforce.com CRM , Oracle Corp., SugarCRM, Salesforce Wave analytics platform and Lattice Engines, which in turn will drive top-line growth.
Earlier, the company acquired NetProspex, a leading B2B professional contact data and data management services provider.
This acquisition is likely to drive growth going forward.
However, increasing competition from companies such as FactSet Research Systems Inc. FDS and Nielsen N.V. NLSN will continue to hurt revenues and profitability in the near term.
Moreover, a high debt level remains a concern.
